problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. If 52 cards are dealt to 8 people as evenly as possible, how many people will end up with fewer than 7 cards?
solution: When you divide 52 by 8, you get 6 with a remainder of 4.  Therefore, 4 of the people will get an extra card, bringing their total to 7, while the remaining $\boxed{4}$ people have only 6 cards.

Since 4 is less than the total number of people (8), there will be some people who receive an additional card, resulting in 7 cards in total. Specifically, 4 people will receive 7 cards and the remaining 4 people will receive 6 cards.

Therefore, there will be 4 people who end up with fewer than 7 cards when 52 cards are dealt to 8 people as evenly as possible.
